turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: I'm so hungry.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: It's cold out, too, isn't it?

turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: I'm so hungry.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Why don't you get a job? If you're so hungry, why don't you get a job?

turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: I lost my job...

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Why? Were you drinking? Is that why you lost it? Insider trading? Just joking. No, really-were you drinking on the job?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Gee, uh, that's too bad.

turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: I'm so hungry.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Why don't you get another one? Why don't , you get another job?

turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: I'm not...

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: You're not what? Qualified for anything else?

turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: I'm hungry

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I know that, I know that. Jeez, you're like a broken record. I'm trying to help you.

turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: I'm hungry.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Listen, do you think it's fair to take money from people who do have jobs? From people who do work?

turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: What am I gonna do?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Listen, what's your name?

turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: Al.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Speak up. Come on.

turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: Al.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Get a goddamn job, Al. You've got a negative attitude. That's what's stopping you. You've got to get your act together. I'll help you.

turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: You re so kind, mister. You're kind. You're a kind man. I can tell.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Shhhh...it's okay.

turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: Please...I don know what to do. I'm so cold.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Do ,you know how bad you smell? The stench, my God.

turns.speaker: HOMELESS MAN
turns.text: I can't...I can't find a shelter

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: You reek. You reek of...shit. Do you know that?  Goddammit, Al-look at me and stop crying like some kind of faggot. Al...I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: Hello, Halberstam. Nice tie. How the hell are you?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: I've been great. And you?

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: How's the Ransom account going, Marcus?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: It's...it's...all right.

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: Really? That's interesting.  Not great?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Oh well, you know.

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: And how's Cecilia? She's a great girl.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Oh yes. I'm very lucky.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Listen, the mud soup and the charcoal arugula are outrageous here.

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: Yeah, well, you're late.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Hey, I'm a child of divorce. Give me a break  Hmmm, I see they've omitted the pork loin with lime jello.

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: We should've gone to Dorsia. I could've gotten us a table.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Nobody goes there anymore.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: So, wasn't Rothschild originally handling the Fisher account? How did you get it?

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: I could tell you that, Halberstam, but then I'd have to kill you.

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: And Cecelia, how is she? Where is she tonight?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Cecelia is, well...you know

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: Evelyn. Great ass. Goes out with that loser Patrick Bateman. What a dork.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Another Martini, Paul?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Paul, give me your Amex card. Good boy. Bateman slaps the card down, looks at the check.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Two-hundred-and-fifty. Very reasonable. Let's leave a big tip, shall we? My place hr a nightcap?

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: No, man. I'm gonna bail.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Come on, you dumb son of a bitch.  I've got a preview of the Barneys catalogue and a bottle of Absolut waiting for us.

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: You like Huey Lewis and the News?

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: They're okay. BATEMAN Their early work was a little too New Wave for my taste. But then Sports came out in 1983, I think they really came into their own, commercially and artistically.

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: Hey, Halberstam?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Yes, Owen?

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: Why are there copies of the Style section all over the place? Do you have a dog? A chow or something?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: No, Owen.

turns.speaker: OWEN
turns.text: Is that a raincoat?

turns.speaker: BATEMAN
turns.text: Yes, it is.

turns.speaker: VAN PATTEN
turns.text: You think so?

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: You'll look like you consciously worked for the look.

turns.speaker: VAN PATTEN
turns.text: Good point. Excuse me, gentlemen.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: How can he lie like that? How can he pull that shit?

turns.speaker: VAN PATTEN
turns.text: What shit? Now where do we have reservations at? I mean I'm not really hungry, but I would like to have reservations somewhere.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: I don't believe it. He looks so...normal. He seems so... out of it. So...undangerous.

turns.speaker: PRICE
turns.text: I just don't see how someone, anyone, can appear that way and yet be involved in such total shit. How can you be so fucking, I don't know, cool about it?

turns.speaker: VAN PATTEN
turns.text: Some guys are just born cool, I guess.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Is it over?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: They still have to give 'em refreshments laced with mind-altering drugs.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: You are a fanatic.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: 'Gonna wait outside.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: Alice? You gotta make him do the start-up with Teddy and me.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: "Make" him?

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You know what I mean.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: I'm just screwed.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: You know what he's like. He just wants to work on stuff that's cool.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: You don't wanna move, do you?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I can paint anywhere.

turns.speaker: LARRY
turns.text: I can't help it. I feel like they'd do anything to keep their --

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Anything? That's not even credible. If he wants to go up there? To check it out? I think you should encourage him.  It's his life. But everybody's treating him like this -- valuable object. You're hurting your own case.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I think I kind of lost it. I was just so thrilled to be talking to the richest, most powerful... 'Didn't know I even cared about that stuff.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: C'mon, how often do you talk to somebody who's been on the cover of Time. Three of four times.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: A lot of what Larry says is true. They just clone stuff, or reverse engineer it, and everybody gets stuck with their inferior version cause they --

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Then you've gotta ask him about that.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: It's important.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: If he's really a bully, he won't cop to it, anyway.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Bully? Are we talking about Gary Boyd? Or your dad.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: When I was a kid? And he was moving us all over the place? I spent all my time writing stuff on Outpost 1.0. I thought Gary Boyd was the greatest.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: But he's not quite the same guy anymore. Don't get your hopes too high?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: If my dad'd leveled with me like that even once... The weird thing is, my fantasy he could somehow be like the old Gary? It's his fantasy, too.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I think that's great, Milo. I do.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: ...But?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Didn't you visit the campus?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I forgot. That's why you have to help me decide.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: No way. You have this -- destiny.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: C'mon, I wouldn't have a destiny without you. My destiny would be dying at 20. From eating --

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Don't bring that up. Like a different girlfriend would'd've let you die?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You saved my life in alot of ways.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: When's Brian coming for the TV?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Prob'ly waiting by the phone for Outpost to call. We'll leave it for him?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: That took some fun out of --

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: We're not gonna let it.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You know he's never been anybody's counselor before?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Milo! What about --?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: To our new life.  ...What's wrong?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: That's what I need to ask you.  You know you can't keep anything from me.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: He gave me some new code-fixes this morning. I said, "Did you really do this just today?" Cause I was impressed. He said "What're you implying?"

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It's the way he said it. Just the way my dad did, when he was caught in a lie. That's how you knew you were onto something ugly.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: What would it mean, anyway? If he didn't write it?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: That's what I'm asking myself. Does he have some genius stowed away? Why not let him write Skywire.  'Not saying it makes sense.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: He's your boss. He's not your --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I know, I know.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: If you can't deal with him on that basis, you better get a new counselor.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Isn't that -- extreme?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: What's extreme is what that ER doctor said when he pumped your stomach. Eat another sesame seed and that's it.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I mean, if one little comment from Gary is gonna upset you this much --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You're right. It's -- a working relationship. Don't know what I was expecting.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: What!

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Teddy was killed last night.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: What're you -- what?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: It was a hate crime.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Are you saying you think they had something to do with his death? Nelson said it was an airtight case.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I don't know what I'm saying. Maybe -- maybe they hired those guys.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I can't see Outpost putting its reputation in the hands of people like that.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I don't know! I just know it was Teddy's code. All these ideas flying in from everywhere. You know how he says "Any kid working in his garage can put us out of business?" It's like they know what every kid's doing.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: They hack into people's programs?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Nobody does work like this on-line. It's in your PC, or in a mainframe. Self-contained. They'd have to be, like, watching people. Physically.  Oh Jesus.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It isn't a broadcast studio. It's -- a surveillance post or something. That's why they have the dishes on top.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: You're scaring me. I think we should just go.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Go where? You can't get away from people like this.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: "Like this?" It's Gary you're talking about.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You think I don't know that?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Milo. Why would he --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: How should I know? "Solving a problem," I guess. Or needing to control everything. I don't know.  I've gotta get in there.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Even if all this were true. There're 20 other buildings. All of them filled with computers and --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It's the only one with dishes on the roof. The studio's a front. That's why they keep postponing its opening.  ...gotta get in there.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Milo, you told me those DOJ Agents are all over the place. How could they hope to hide a surveillance post?  And how can you get in there, anyway? With the cameras and the swipe cards --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I can't just walk away!

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: You can't just walk in, either.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: They stop the construction work at six or seven. The parking lot's mostly clear by two or three in the morning. Even the early Geeks don't get there before five.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Is it two? Or is it three? Have you ever really noticed?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I know how to get in there. But you've gotta help me.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: ...Whaddo I do?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: So you believe me?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: It's almost nine, I've been so worried!  What did you see in there?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Nothing?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It's what they said it is. An unfinished broadcast studio. You were right... I just drove to Seattle and back.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: ...Why?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Remember Lyle Barton?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: The Justice Department guy who came to the apartment when --

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I remember.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: After I broke into 21 -- which was insane, thank God they didn't catch me! -- I just drove around. Trying to figure out what possessed me. You know what? I've been putting my own guilt on Gary.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Guilt?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: If I'd stayed down there, maybe this wouldn't've happened.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Poor baby. You know that's not true.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: That was -- different.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: ...Different?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Where were you?  You know you can't keep anything from me.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Okay, yeah. I did something naughty... There's this amazing Comix store in Seattle.  To tell you the truth, I did it once or twice at Stanford. 'Guess I can't keep anything from you...

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Look at this.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Why doesn't he ask us to his party. He's never even met you.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: He has thousands of employees, Milo --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It's for the Museum. He knows you're a painter. If anybody should be invited --

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Milo --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I know you think I'm too attached to him, but still. I am close to Gary. And you're the most meaningful person in my life.  I'm going back to the Comix place, why should I be killing myself.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Milo, you --

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Are you gonna tell me where you went?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I went to see the Skywire model in Gary's office. You know. Just to hold it again.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: No. No. I sent an E-mail to somebody, just now. To tell her how I feel about you.  You know I'm clueless, without you. You know I --

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Just shut up?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Great!

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Look at me! I'm gonna change.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You look beautiful.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Yeah? Give me a goodbye kiss.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: ...What?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I know you. You're gonna run back to work right after dinner. I want my kiss now.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Milo?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Don't we have any chopsticks?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Oh, right. Hold on.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Here we go.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: ...wanna savor this.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: It's gonna get cold.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Right. Wait. A toast.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: You're just afraid to eat it.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: 'Didn't mention he was going to the Justice Department?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Not like him, is it? To do a thing like that without telling you. You're not losing your hold on him, are you?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: He'll tell me when he gets home.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: That'll be a test, won't it?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Instead of busting my chops you should do something about that girl. Fire her. Or something.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Lisa's an extremely valuable member of the Skywire team. We've got our eyes on her. You keep yours on Milo.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Prick.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: He said it made sense that Gary's code was like Teddy's, that that cliché about great minds was true. Said it was all about his own guilt.  Plus, he has a tendency to get Gary mixed-up with his dad once in a while. It always passes.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: He wasn't acting?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: I don't think he knows how.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Don't worry, Milo. I'm here as a friend. Or maybe a supplicant.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Right... What's that mean again?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Beggar. We're at a disadvantage with Outpost. Our experts aren't as smart as theirs. Sometimes we can't tell which technologies pose the threat of a monopoly. We need a really smart guy to help us pick our fights. I'm taking a shot in the dark, here. I can offer you 32,000 a year, a Buick. I'm hoping you've got a feeling it's the right thing to do.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It's just -- I kind of feel the need to do something with my ability. Create something...

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Like I said: shot in the dark.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Mr. Barton, do you remember me?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: ...It's -- Milo, isn't it?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Yes sir. I need to talk to you.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Give me two seconds with Lacy here?  Go on in, I won't be a moment.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Milo?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Yeah. Hi. Thank you for seeing me.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Have a seat.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: What seems to be the problem? You look a little upset.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I am. I am, sir.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Milo?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: My friend, my best friend, Teddy, was killed in Silicon Valley.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: My goodness.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It was racially motivated. He's Chinese. He was. And... I know sometimes the FBI gets involved with that. Don't they?

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: If there's a Civil Rights violation. But generally we let the local police and DA do their work first.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I -- just wanna help bring these guys to justice. They're neo-Nazis.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: Let me look into it, see what's being done. Frankly, it's not my area.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: 'Just didn't know who else to talk to.

turns.speaker: BARTON
turns.text: And Outpost? You're happy there?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You're living here?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: 'Thought if I relocated it could help my case. I'm writing programs for the local public access station. Where any whack-job with 100 bucks gets his own show? God, does it suck.  Can you help me?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Sure, I'll see what I can do.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Well I parked illegally. See y'later?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: 'Forgot to introduce you.  I have a girlfriend.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: This is the biggest Beta demo in like the history of software. You'd be my partner.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: You can't pre-empt Yoga, that's our biggest show.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Brian! You wanna be a big deal, don't you? That's your dream in life.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Will I get to work for Outpost?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: No. But you can write your own ticket in the Valley after this. We're gonna bring down Outpost.

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: What'd they ever do for you?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Great. Great! We need to drag a lot of heavy stuff in front of the door --

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What?!

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Wanna be a part of history?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: You're interfaced with our dish.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Gimme the coordinates?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: Is it your software?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Is it your dish?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: What?!

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: He's working backwards, too.  Let's do number five?

turns.speaker: BRIAN
turns.text: ...When did you know?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You should've called a few times to bug me about your job prospects.

turns.speaker: LARRY KING
turns.text: That's gotta kill him, right?

turns.speaker: CYBER PUNDIT
turns.text: Outpost was his baby, sure. On the other hand, we just learned Gary Boyd owns the Skywire satellites. Personally.

turns.speaker: LARRY KING
turns.text: Outpost doesn't own em.

turns.speaker: CYBER PUNDIT
turns.text: Conglomerates're lined up to finance the launch of the remaining satellites. They'll pay him a huge premium to get on-line.

turns.speaker: LARRY KING
turns.text: That'd change with a criminal indictment.

turns.speaker: CYBER PUNDIT
turns.text: There's no hard evidence he knew about this. Anybody who could implicate him seems to've vanished.

turns.speaker: LARRY KING
turns.text: Isn't there a stigma? Bankrolling this guy?

turns.speaker: CYBER PUNDIT
turns.text: Stigma? Larry! 60 billion buys you some slack in this world.

turns.speaker: LARRY KING
turns.text: And the kid who wrote Skywire -- then gave it away? They're calling him the digital Robin Hood.

turns.speaker: CYBER PUNDIT
turns.text: Milo. Surprised he's not your guest.

turns.speaker: LARRY KING
turns.text: We tried!

turns.speaker: CYBER PUNDIT
turns.text: You better believe everybody's trying to sign him up.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Milo? I'm Danny.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Oh hi.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: 'Couldn't convince Teddy to come?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: He's pretty tight with his family.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: We could move 'em up here.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: He just likes to write code. He's bummed there's so much secrecy and competition, everybody trying to own everything.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Who's that?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: I think they call him the "Houseman." 'Cause "guard" sounds too weird.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: ...Hello?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Milo? Gary Boyd. I'm hoping you and your friend can come up here. We've made some amazing strides in digital convergence. I'd love to show them to you.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You would? Wow. When would we come?  'Think he hung up.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Cool!

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Would you like a Coke or something?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Oh. No thanks.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You know a lot about art, I guess.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: There's a rumor going around, maybe you've heard it.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: I've only shown this to three other people. I bought 200, we've launched 12 so far. I keep the coordinates in this room.  It's left over from SDI. Reagan's Star Wars technology? They orbit 426 miles up.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Low enough to relay internet traffic.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Among other things... We know convergence is the real super-highway: all the PC's, TV's, phones, etc. linked together. Why cram it into a cable if you can use the whole sky?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Skywire.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: The content filer has t'be written into the media files so bits coming off the satellite can be read by multiplatforms. Really, omniplatforms. Including whatever new hardware emerges.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It needs a more object-oriented language. This doesn't scale, does it?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: You'd have to start practically from scratch. But this is all you'd be working on. No marketing meetings, no product seminars. We can't waste the time. Half the Valley's working on convergence. So're media conglomerates, cable companies, phone companies. 'Can't finish second, Milo. There is no second... Now what would you like to ask me?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: When you get to a certain age, you start wondering. About your legacy. I doubt you even remember Outpost 1.0 --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I do!

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Yeah? I wanna feel like I did when I wrote that. But I'm 42, that's 100 in cyber-years. I look at you and see the things that got me here.  But somehow got away.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: No! Just waiting for my counselor to come by and introduce himself.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Okay. I'm Gary.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: 'Think I should buy some originals?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: ...Do I?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Somebody said I'm just another Philistine. With reproductions.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: That's insane. You're ahead of your time.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: That's what I told her. My wife.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Could work with a new switch. There may be a few more things hidden.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Don't spend too much time searching. You ever vetted somebody's old code before?  It's a different skill. Stay close to the surface. The best-hidden secrets are in plain sight. You know the best place to hide a leaf, right?  In a tree.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: How's it going?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Maybe I'm going too fast.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Too fast? At least four companies're on the verge of workable convergence systems, Milo, they --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It's okay. Really.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Take a look at this. Slightly different approach.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You did this -- overnight?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: You're making me young again.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Milo. What's up?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Well -- you sent for me.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Right... Right.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: You really wrote this just today?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: What're you implying.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Nothing!

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Everything I do is under scrutiny. The questions they ask, trying to make anything strategic look sordid.  I'm confused. Doesn't everybody in business try to get ahead?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I'm sure.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: The purpose of this company isn't to destroy our competitors any more than the purpose of living is to breath. But the software business is binary: you're a zero or a one. Being obsessive isn't a crime. It's a character trait.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: It scales, don't you think?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Definitely.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: I heard what happened.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Were the flags for Teddy?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Had you talked to him much lately?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Just once. 'Guess I was worried we didn't have anything to talk about, since work was off-limits. Non- disclosure.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Did you?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Talk about work? Never!

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: I meant did you find other stuff to --

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Oh. Yeah.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: You've been coming in early.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: It helps. Alice said it would help. To focus on something.  'Don't know what I'd do without her.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Wow. You must have 20,000 lines of code there...

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: 34,000. But they're real short lines. 'Just came out that way.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Been thinking about the push mechanism in the handler. And it came over me: it's in the wrong place.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: The wrong place?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: The answer's not in the box. It's in the band.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Gary, hi.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: You look a little tired.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I'm okay. It's going well!

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: 'Have a look?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Why did you move around so much? When you were a kid.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: ...My dad was a compulsive gambler. Only he didn't think he was. That applied to guys who didn't have a "system." "Losers," who played games of chance. He could "read" people, so chance had nothing to do with it. No matter how deep a hole he dug himself, he'd give you the whole speech. And you'd better not point out the obvious.  His creditors would catch up to him. Loan sharks or whatever. He'd wake us in the middle of the night. Off we'd go, again.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: What would you tell the kids? At your new school? You had to come up with a good story, right?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: No. I just went deeper into the machine. Preferred being the geek to having to explain. Lying would've been worse.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: ...Worse?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Cause he was a liar. And I hated him.  "Get your head out of that machine, wise up to the real world." The more he mocked me the deeper I went. Cause if being savvy meant being like him --  Guess that's why I'm kind of clueless, even now. Didn't cultivate my conniving side. 'Not sure I even have one.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Don't be so hard on yourself. With a brain like yours, you could connive with the best of 'em I bet.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: That's great! Thanks.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: 'Sorry about the late notice...

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: "Dear Lisa. I've enjoyed working with you. I'd be lying if I didn't say I find you attractive. But in my heart I know that Alice..."  You left my party to send E-mail?

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I couldn't do it at work cause of security or at home for -- obvious reasons.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: You could've handwritten it.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I'm not much good at handwriting. Or parties.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Oh, that's right. You're "clueless."

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: Gary, I --

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: You see what's hanging on the wall?

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: I hope you know what you mean to me. Not just because of what you're doing. Because of who you are.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I do know, Gary. I feel the same way. I thought I was coming here for a job. But it's meant a lot more.

turns.speaker: MILO
turns.text: I'm pretty close. But when I wrote the last contact switches, it wiped out a piece of the content filer. You know what it's like, writing software.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: I do know. You focus on the big problem. But somewhere down the chain, something breaks down. Something gets destroyed. At first it's upsetting. You feel you've lost control.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: This is good. Who did it?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: 'Start-up not 50 miles from here. Kid's on Prozac.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Maybe we should all get on it.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: What'd the girl say?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: There may be a little less trust after your outburst.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Hasn't affected his work, though.

turns.speaker: GARY
turns.text: Nothing does. Still. I want him to like me.
